ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned about the diversity of life on Earth, from the smallest of prokaryotes to the larger ecosystems of rivers. We studied the anatomy of animals and developed skills to understand the diversity of life using morphological characteristics. We also developed quantitative skills in determining biodiversity in stream habitats.
I learned some lab techniques as well as identification of various branches of the tree of life and how evolution has led to these traits.
I learned about the principles of ecology and evolutionary biology and about lab strategies used in research.
Introduction to evolution and ecology in the laboratory context.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The largest strength of this course is Dr. Marta Wells, who made this entire lab an amazing experience. The curriculum she uses is methodical and keeps you engaged with diversity of life. I cannot think of any improvements that need to be made to this course.
I thought the labs were wonderful and very engaging and the handbooks before hand gave a good amount of information beforehand.

Strengths: Lab was super fun. This was a rare STEM class that really focuses on student engagement. The TAs and Professor Wells were wonderful--some of the best I've had at Yale. 

Weaknesses: The lab reports were pretty time consuming. The workload outside of class was very high--especially for a half credit course.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The split between zoom and in person was great- sometimes if in person I didn't catch something, knowing that it was available online as well was helpful.

The teaching team put in a lot of effort to make the course accessible to both in person and remote students, and I really appreciated that. However, the hybrid set-up of this course (having some students in person and some students remote) was very challenging at times. There were often technical difficulties (camera problems, audio problems, etc.) on the teaching team's end, and this made it difficult for me to engage with the course as a remote student. I think it would have been very helpful if the teaching team had taken some time at the beginning of the semester to practice using the camera and to work out the technical elements required for the class, so that these difficulties wouldn't have come up so many times over the course of the semester. Additionally, it took quite a long time to receive feedback on any of the lab reports. By the time the first one was graded, we had already handed in almost half of our assignments -- the lack of intermittent feedback made it difficult for me to make adjustments / improvements on my subsequent reports.
In-person lab was safe and fun.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would absolutely recommend this class to anyone interested in ecology or evolutionary biology. This course is one of the best lab courses on campus, and I cannot recommend it highly enough. The professor, the TA's (which I assume will be high quality since they come largely from the E&EB department), and the curriculum are all high quality.
Yes, I loved this class so much- it was so engaging, Professor Wells is incredible, and the TFs were so helpful.
Yes, the instructors were awesome and lab was genuinely fun. However, the workload was pretty high for a half credit class.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: There was also a remote component for students who could not attend in person.
This lab class had some in-person students and some virtual students. I completed the lab as a remote / virtual student.
